senses.definition: no longer successful and unlikely to succeed again in the future

examples.x: Her singing career was all washed up by the time she was 27.

senses.definition: an event, etc. that is a complete failure, especially because of rain

examples.x: They feared that the wedding was going to be a washout after torrential rain.

senses.definition: unsuccessful because it does not produce the result you wanted

examples.x: We had a wasted trip—they weren't in.

senses.definition: too thin, especially because of illness

examples.x: thin wasted legs

senses.definition: strongly affected by alcohol or drugs
intending to be helpful or useful but not always succeeding very well
intending to do what is right and helpful but often not succeeding

examples.x: a well-meaning attempt to be helpful
He's very well meaning.

senses.definition: done, said, etc. in order to be helpful but often not succeeding

examples.x: well-meant comments
His offer was well meant.

senses.definition: an act of pushing something/somebody

examples.x: She gave him a gentle push.
The car won't start. Can you give it a push?
At the push of a button (= very easily) he could get a whole list of names.

senses.definition: a large and determined military attack

examples.x: a final push against the enemy
The firm has begun a major push into the European market.

senses.definition: a determined effort to achieve something

examples.x: The push for reform started in 2007.

senses.definition: an act of encouraging somebody to do something

examples.x: He wants to open his own business, but needs a push in the right direction to get him started.

senses.definition: a wildcat strike happens suddenly and without the official support of a trade union wildcat strike

examples.x: Agreement was reached after several days of wildcat strikes.
The aim of the law is to prevent wildcat stoppages.

senses.definition: that has not been carefully planned and that will probably not be successful; that does not follow normal standards and methods
to be the most successful in a competition, race, battle, etc.

examples.x: Which team won?
to win an election
to win a game/race/war/battle
She loves to win an argument.
to win at cards/chess
France won by six goals to two against Denmark.

senses.definition: to get something as the result of a competition, race, election, etc. one

examples.x: Britain won five gold medals.
He won £3 000 in the lottery.
How many states did the Republicans win?
Everyone who takes part wins a small prize.
to win an award/a title
The Conservatives won the seat from Labour in the last election.
You've won yourself a trip to New York.

senses.definition: to achieve or get something that you want, especially by your own efforts

examples.x: They are trying to win support for their proposals.
The company has won a contract to supply books and materials to schools.
She won the admiration of many people in her battle against cancer.

senses.definition: complete failure, defeat or destruction

examples.x: The party faces virtual wipeout in the election.
a 5–0 wipeout

senses.definition: a fall from a surfboard
a vehicle that has been so badly damaged in an accident that cannot be repaired or would cost more to repair than to replace

examples.x: She survived the crash with minor injuries, but the car was a write-off.

senses.definition: a period of time during which you do not achieve anything

examples.x: With meetings and phone calls, yesterday was a complete write-off.

senses.definition: an act of cancelling a debt and accepting that it will never be paid
to cancel a debt; to recognize that something is a failure, has no value, etc.

examples.x: to write off a debt/an investment

senses.definition: to damage something, especially a vehicle, so badly that it cannot be repaired or would cost more to repair than to replace

examples.x: He’s written off two cars this year.

senses.definition: to be the most successful in a competition, race, battle, etc.

examples.x: Which team won?
to win an election
to win a game/race/war/battle
She loves to win an argument.
to win at cards/chess
France won by six goals to two against Denmark.

senses.definition: to get something as the result of a competition, race, election, etc. one

examples.x: Britain won five gold medals.
He won £3 000 in the lottery.
How many states did the Republicans win?
Everyone who takes part wins a small prize.
to win an award/a title
The Conservatives won the seat from Labour in the last election.
You've won yourself a trip to New York.

examples.x: They are trying to win support for their proposals.
The company has won a contract to supply books and materials to schools.
She won the admiration of many people in her battle against cancer.

senses.definition: used to describe the group of people who are considered to be the least famous, successful or important, especially in entertainment Z-list

examples.x: There are too many reality shows featuring Z-list celebrities.

senses.definition: one of a group of people who are considered to be the least famous, successful or important, especially in entertainment
